text: In the late 80s, my dad decided he wanted to work for himself, so he quit his job and started his own business installing alarm systems. Shortly after that my mom got pregnant with my sister, but when my dad gave up working for a boss he also gave up my family’s health insurance.  When my mom went to her doctor to figure out how much having a baby without insurance would cost, she was told she’d need to pay $5,000 just for the doctor’s services. Oh, and because she didn’t have insurance, they’d require that payment in full by the fourth month of her pregnancy. When my mom balked at paying so early, she was dismissed and told she could just go to the free clinic if she couldn’t afford it. When my mom tells this story, even after all this time, you can hear how hurt she was in that moment. This is what a for-profit healthcare system continues to do today — value people based on their ability to pay. The last thing a pregnant person should be doing is stressing about the costs of birth. We absolutely don’t have to live this way. And with Medicare for All, we won’t.

We recently canvassed a woman who didn't know where to vote because her normal polling place was Pulaski Elementary, which closed last year. We checked on the Department of Elections website and her polling place was still listed as Pulaski. We called the Department of Elections 3 times: got hung up on once, transferred to the Dover campaign finance department, then finally got through to someone on the third try. They said that her new polling place would either be Richardson Park or Claymore Senior Center...but they hadn't finalized it yet.  The school has been closed for almost a year. The presidential primary election is in 8 weeks.  I'm furious. There are people looking up where to vote who are getting the wrong polling place and won't know where to vote on election day. We asked them to put something on the website to let people know, but they said they probably wouldn't do that; they will just send people new polling cards when they finally decide where their new polling places are. And when people DO learn where they can vote, there are still concerns about how they will get to their new polling place. I talked to another woman in Browntown this weekend who told us her husband got his new polling place card that said they'll vote at Richardson Park, but she was really concerned about people — especially the elderly or those who don't drive — being able to get there. This is voter suppression at work. **UPDATE ** We followed up with this voter and she received her new voter card in the mail yesterday. The Department of Elections website has been updated with the correct polling location. There are many others out there who may have checked the Department of Elections website before these updates and have incorrect information about where to vote. If you have not received your updated voter card, or are unsure where to vote, please check ivote.de.gov or message us for help!

This is Wilmington in 1968. Delaware’s governor deployed thousands of National Guard members to Wilmington to stifle protests after Dr. King's assassination, resulting in the longest peacetime occupation of an American city. The mostly white National Guard force kept the city under strict surveillance for 9 months, forcing businesses to close, trapping residents in their homes, and resulting in the murder of Douglas Henry Jr., who was shot to death even as he was complying with the guardsman’s orders. After the occupation ended, residents whose homes and businesses were damaged or closed never received compensation for their losses. Residents with lasting trauma from being violently surveilled never received the care they deserved. #BlackHistoryMonth is about more than remembering our history of anti-Black racism, it's about repairing the harm we've done and taking action to dismantle the systemic oppression that persists today. This is why I support reparations: just because a racist occupation or law no longer exists, the damage is already done. We can’t begin to repair these wrongs until we fairly compensate those who suffered under them. 📸: The News Journal

In Riverside, residents step outside their doors and find almost constant surveillance by police and signs posted everywhere telling them not to loiter in their own yards.  A resident I spoke to told me how she was given a citation by police for leaning on the hood of her own car with a friend. While enjoying a nice evening outside in front of her home they were harassed by police, told to leave, and ticketed when they refused. Knowing she was wrongfully cited, she decided to fight it in court. The judge agreed with her, said the citation was completely unfounded, and threw it out. And sure, she left court that day not owing any fines, but she never should have had to go in the first place.  Instead of using our tax dollars to treat the root causes of the poverty and lift everyone up, our government opts to spend money on stripping people of their freedom and dignity. We have to end this and do better by everyone. Let’s fight poverty, not the poor.

It is state-sanctioned violence that we don’t guarantee a good standard of living to every person in this country. We can’t expect to fix gun violence while our elected officials refuse to fight for universal healthcare, a livable minimum wage, and guaranteed housing. We need leaders who will fight against a system that strips people of their agency, their humanity, and their will, condemning them to violence. We owe it to our neighbors, our children, and our community.

Bill and I met 15 years ago this week. Our first date was just 2 days before Valentine’s Day, so I obviously wasn’t thinking we’d be exchanging any gifts. Bill, however, had a different idea. This guy I’d known for about 48 hours knocked on my apartment door to give me a mix CD.  Because that’s who Bill is — thoughtful and generous and sincere. Oh, and likely to communicate via music. Our relationship has made me a better person. It’s softened my outer shell of cynicism and skepticism, made me more open-hearted, and helped me cement the justice-oriented values I hold. Plus, it’s great to have someone you can talk (read: yell) to about the many things we have to fix in the world. So, today and every day remember to treat the people in your life — whether they’re spouses, siblings, friends, parents, or strangers on the street — with love and compassion. It’s how we’ll make a better future.

I was talking to a mother whose son is living with several mental illnesses. She told me how helpless she felt when her child would suffer episodes. Calling an ambulance or a trip to the ER cost thousands of dollars they could not afford. She wanted to take him to treatment and therapy more consistently, but each session cost over a hundred dollars, which they couldn't afford without sacrificing rent money. When her son was in crisis, she felt she had no viable options to help him.  If only mental healthcare options weren't so prohibitly expensive. If only we had more clinics who could accept more patients, give them quality care, and not have clients jump through a million hoops to see if they are in network. If only we had a health system that emphasized early and preventative services, rather that just post-crisis care. Mental health shouldn't be a luxury only afforded to those with enough money. And our criminal legal system definitely should not be used as a substitute for treatment. Ensuring that mental health care is included in our fight for Medicare for All is a necessity and a major priority for our campaign.

That’s why I am fighting for a federal housing guarantee, a federal Tenant’s Bill of Rights, increased funding to expand our public housing, and financial industry oversight to end predatory lending, redlining, and racial segregation.

In 1929, Louis L. Redding, a graduate of Brown University, Harvard Law, and Delaware's own Howard High School, became the first Black lawyer in the state of Delaware. He remained the only non-white attorney for the next 25 years.  As an NAACP attorney and public defender, Redding fought for the civil rights and liberties of Black people. He successfully fought to desegregate the University of Delaware and public schools in Hockessin and Claymont, which paved the way for Supreme Court cases like Brown v. Board of Education, which overruled the "separate but equal" doctrine in public schools, and Burton v. Wilmington Parking Authority, which prohibited segregation in public accommodations. Delaware has a difficult history of racial injustice that continues to this day. We honor Louis Redding's legacy by continuing the fight for racial equity and justice. #BlackHistoryMonth

Today marks the first day of Black History Month. American history IS Black history; this country was built on the exploitation of Black people. Wilmington, where I live, is a majority Black city, and I’m particularly grateful this month for the ways that our city’s Black residents have built our culture, art, businesses, and communities. But we also need to confront our country’s pervasive anti-Black racism. From police brutality, to racist redlining practices, to school segregation, to the polluted air and water in our majority-Black neighborhoods: we are a long way from achieving racial justice. Let’s fight together for an anti-racist agenda. We have to do better than providing “equal opportunities”...we must pass redistributive policies that will center Black people’s needs.

"My parents immigrated back in the 90's, and while they were green card holders, they didn't qualify for Medicaid due to their status. My father was covered by his doctorate program, but my mother didn't have health insurance, and couldn't find work because she was pregnant. Because of the extremely high costs, she wouldn't see doctors unless absolutely necessary. Something as mundane as a UTI would develop into frequent kidney infections, and she would end up being taken to the ER suffering high fevers, putting her life in danger every time. Until my father found a job years later that covered our whole family, the fear of deciding between treating illness or going thousands of dollars in debt constantly loomed over us. In our current healthcare system, having a green card and waiting almost a decade for citizen status can mean almost a decade without being covered. It's ridiculous that our healthcare is treated as a privilege and not a right." - Margaret This is why we NEED Medicare for All, because the human cost of not having universal healthcare is already far too high.

Last week Senator Coons voted in favor of Trump’s NAFTA 2.0 trade deal, the USMCA. This is a trade deal that: 🔹 Completely ignores the reality and threat of climate change 🔹 Allows companies to move from the US to Mexico where environmental regulations are weaker 🔹 Rewards oil and gas companies by prohibiting tariffs on their products Last year, I asked Delaware’s federal delegation to reject the USMCA. The estimates I received back from them touted that the trade deal would add 176,000 jobs and $68 billion to the economy. While those job numbers may sound impressive, realistically that’s equal to one month of less-than-average job growth, with no guarantee of the quality or wages of those jobs. Meanwhile, the $68 billion in GDP growth is sure to line the pockets of executives and investors of BigAg and industry. Like NAFTA before it, this deal fails to adequately protect workers and the planet.

I was talking to a voter about her child's education. Her son had a learning disability, and as a result, also had an Individualized Education Plan (IEP). When he was in middle school, his IEP allowed him to thrive, with smaller classroom sizes, more individualized attention, and the flexibility to take a walk when he needed to cool off. He even made honor roll. But when her son entered high school, everything changed. There weren't enough teachers to provide him or other students with disabilities the attention they needed in order to succeed.  These kids are every bit as bright and talented as kids from any other school, but we're not giving them the resources they need to thrive. Delaware is failing tens of thousands of children, who are disproportionately low-income, have disabilities, and are from communities of color. We need to fund our schools equitably, because EVERY child deserves a quality education, regardless of their race, income, or the neighborhood they live in. This is an article from 2018, but this lawsuit is still ongoing and these stories are just as relevant today.

Happy Martin Luther King Jr. Day! Today is a national day of service, and as a white woman, I am reflecting on the ways in which I must step up to dismantle white supremacy. Dr. King, and all Black activists of the Civil Rights era, struggled and sacrificed for the important gains our country has achieved. But we still have a long way to go in dismantling white supremacy. Here in Delaware, anti-Black racism continues to permeate every aspect of our daily lives. ✖️Our neighborhoods are highly segregated, in part due to racist redlining practices. ✖️Our majority-Black neighborhoods are suffering from disproportionately high cancer rates. ✖️Our state’s Black maternal health outcomes are shockingly worse than outcomes for white women. ✖️The majority of folks incarcerated in Delaware are Black.     This country was built with labor stolen from Black people. They have never been repaid for the ways that we have dehumanized them, and their continued exploitation for our economic gain. Dr. King was committed to fighting oppression at the intersection of racism and capitalism. Let us follow his example today, and every day, to fight white supremacy and support redistributive policies that center the needs of Black communities.

I talked to a voter who had previously struggled with opioid addiction after he broke his hand playing basketball. His doctor prescribed him Percocets. But, after his scrip ran out, he found that he was still suffering unbearable pain, so much so that it was affecting his ability to perform at his job. He couldn't get a doctor to write him another prescription, so in order to manage both the pain and keep his job, he resorted to buying opiates on the streets. The desperation to maintain his job, especially as his family's sole wage earner, and keep providing for his children, drove him further and further into dependency.  The worst part, he said, was the stigma he faced when he sought recovery. "When a doctor prescribes you opioids, it's fine. But once you get it elsewhere, you're a drug addict." I've heard so many similar stories from people who are in the midst of recovery. They are injured on the job or via sports or through a car accident, are given strong opioid prescriptions to manage the pain, and then left hanging when those scrips run out. They keep their addiction hidden because of the shame, often leading to a downward spiral. And when they finally muster the courage to seek help, they face negative stigma and expensive treatment programs. When we talk about the opioid crisis, we need to remember that that crisis lives in our own communities, and the devastation addiction wrecks on individual's lives. Pushing people to seclude themselves and their struggles will not solve this. The fault does not lie with individuals struggling with addiction, but with the pharmaceutical companies that pushed opioids onto MILLIONS. We need to hold Big Pharma accountable for the harm they have inflicted and make sure we fund quality treatment programs that are accessible for all.  https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/heroindelaware/2019/08/21/delaware-making-gains-fighting-overdoses-so-why-more-people-still-dying/2011099001/

In 2010, I was laid off and had to go on unemployment to get by. The experience was, frankly, dehumanizing and demoralizing. But it drove my belief in our need for universal programs and here’s why: If you've been on unemployment, you know that the system is designed to make it difficult to receive your benefits. Every week I had to: ➕ Keep records of how many jobs I’d applied to, in case the state wanted to call them to confirm I’d actually applied. ➕ Drive more than an hour to attend meetings and trainings with the Labor Department. ➕ Report if I received any job offers, because we were required to accept an offer of “suitable work” even if it meant lower pay, a longer commute, or less responsibility than our previous job. The whole time, I was shamed by the people I loved. They had such elitist and nasty opinions of people who receive government assistance, which were perpetuated by stereotypes in the media. But the reality is, none of us are stereotypes; we're real people, and most Americans are an illness or emergency away from being in the same situation. When we means-test and add unnecessary bureaucracy to programs, we weaken them and stigmatize those who need them. Instead, we should all contribute and we should all receive. If it’s not a system for everyone, it’s not a sustainable system.

We were promised a college education was the ticket to success and a life without struggle. But these days, the cost of that ticket is unaffordable, and some of our own elected leaders helped it get this way. When I look around I see my friends, family, and coworkers saddled with huge amounts of debt just because they did what they were told they needed to do to succeed. A former coworker of mine, just months out of school, owed his loan servicer more than $1,000 a month. It inhibited his ability to make rent, maintain his car, or have any kind of life outside of the 2 jobs he had to work just to pay the bills. He's not alone. This story is so many people's story. Many of our team members are either racking up student debt, or trying to pay it off. Instead of prosperity, we have a generation convinced they’ll never get out of debt. We already collectively fund public K-12 education. The high school diploma you'd get from that school used to be enough to set you up for a dignified life, but we know it's not a guarantee anymore. Now is the time to forgive student debt and make public colleges and trade schools tuition-free to ensure everyone can get the education they need to be successful.

I meet so many people out canvassing who are working minimum wage jobs and fighting tirelessly to provide for themselves and their families. Once upon a time, a minimum wage job could keep a single-parent out of poverty. But the minimum wage has not kept up with the cost of living.  Right now, the minimum wage in Delaware is $9.25/hour. But according to the National Low Income Housing Coalition, you need to make at least $21.97/hour to afford a basic 2-bedroom rental in Delaware. That means a parent working a minimum wage job right now would have to work almost 100 hours/week just to make rent. We need guaranteed housing, and we need to raise the minimum wage to a LIVABLE wage (and tie it to inflation) so that no one has to struggle to feed, clothe, and support a household on a minimum wage job.

Over the holidays my dad told a story of how he used to take me along on his jobs installing alarm systems in people’s homes. I admit it’s a cute story (and all that time together definitely made us buds) but it also speaks to the sad state of childcare in our country. We were lucky my dad could bring me along to work. Very few people have that option...and in the 30+ years since, we still haven’t given families any better options. It's time for us to make childcare free for all families. I spoke with Deedra recently, and she told me about her landlord's negligence. I sued the owner unsuccessfully and now have been asked to vacate the premises immediately. At this point I feel helpless, permanently disabled and my income is limited. My daughter my grandson and I must find housing elsewhere immediately. Stories like this are why I'm fighting for guaranteed housing and a federal Tenants' Bill of Rights. Housing is a human right, but Deedra and her family can't wait for the laws to change. If you are able, please consider donating to help them with moving expenses.

A voter asked me: "What would you replace cash bail with?"   The answer is nothing. Cash bail doesn't serve any purpose except to criminalize poverty. Can’t afford bail? You might remain incarcerated for MONTHS while your case is processed. Meanwhile, a wealthy person in this same situation could walk free and await their trial from home. More than 60% of our prison population are folks who haven't yet been convicted of a crime, and 30% are people who simply can't afford to post bail. Most of these detainees have been accused of low level offenses and are overwhelmingly Black and Latinx. This is a racist and classist system, full stop. Being held for weeks, or even months, destroys lives - people lose their jobs, can't care for their children, and miss payments for rent. Out of desperation, people are more likely to take plea deals so they can be released, even if they are innocent. Our bail system punishes people for being poor. States from Alabama to California have recognized this, and enacted reforms strictly curtailing cash bail. It's about time Delaware joins them, and stops criminalizing poverty.    https://theappeal.org/bail-reform-explained-4abb73dd2e8a/

When I moved to Delaware, I started tutoring at the West End Neighborhood House, a Wilmington organization that offers programs for children and families focused on education, employment, and housing. I consistently tutored one student, Mekhi, and I felt so lucky when he eventually trusted me enough to ask for advice and share what was going on with his day, his friends, and his family. Over that year I watched him go from trying to convince me that he didn’t have any reading homework to reading chapter books. I also saw his confidence grow and his willingness to speak up for himself blossom.  West End’s work shows that providing wraparound, community-building services to support the whole family leads to stronger neighborhoods and more successful outcomes. But what about students who live a few blocks too far from West End? What about students whose parents are unaware of what West End offers? We can’t expect small, local nonprofits to cover 100% of students’ needs throughout this state and country. When elected, I’ll fight for the federal funding that’s needed to enact this model across the country and ensure all our public schools have the resources they need to be pillars of strength for our communities. In the meantime, learn more about the great work West End Neighborhood House is doing below. http://www.westendnh.org/

New parents in the UK get up to 39 weeks of paid leave. Canadians get a full year of paid leave. The average mother in the US takes just 10 weeks of unpaid leave.  When my mom gave birth to me she had just 6 weeks of unpaid leave. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 granted eligible workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for a new child. That was a huge step...26 years ago. We can do better. We deserve better. The majority of Americans can’t afford a $400 emergency expense; how can we expect most mothers to afford 12 weeks of unpaid leave? Furthermore, the 1993 bill doesn’t cover fathers, so the full burden of care rests with the mother. This country needs a new family leave mandate and it can't just apply to federal workers. We must guarantee fully paid leave for all birth and adoptive parents.

Fun fact: Delaware has some of the worst civil forfeiture laws in the country.  For example, if a person is arrested with their wallet and cell phone on them, the police can seize these items as evidence. The items they seize can include valuables like money, wallets, phones, and CARS.  People have an extremely low chance of ever getting their belongings back, even if they're proven innocent. Law enforcement can then use the profits  to do.... whatever they want. Seriously.  There is NO legal accountability to track where any of this goes.  These civil forfeiture laws encourage police to abuse their power and prey on innocent people, just to seize their property. It's theft. We need reform now.  https://ij.org/pfp-state-pages/pfp-delaware/

The attack on Pearl Harbor was a tragic event in our history, and today we remember and mourn the lives lost that day. But we must do more than mourn those who were killed: we must reject the imperialism and hubris that led to this tragedy. Our country violently colonized Hawai'i and established a military base on Oahu. How many lives were lost to US imperialism before that attack on December 7, 1941? During this time of increasing global antisemitism and right-wing authoritarianism, the legacy of World War 2 is a good reminder that we must oppose hatred and bigotry now, or doom ourselves to repeat history. We should always honor those who laid down their lives in the fight against white supremacy, antisemitism, and authoritarianism. But let us remember those who lost their lives to US imperialism even before that fateful attack on Pearl Harbor, and those who are still suffering under the thumb of our oppression.  Let us go forward and repay those debts by ending our imperialism and exploitation, supporting peoples’ right to self-determination, and building a legacy of peace, not war.

Today is World AIDS Day, a day where we remember those we have lost to AIDS and support our friends, family, and neighbors living with HIV.    We have come a long way in the treatment and de-stigmatization of HIV and AIDS, but we still have a long way to go. Antiretroviral treatments have advanced so much that they can reduce HIV levels to undetectable and prevent transmission when taken daily. But the cost of these medications — medications people rely on to survive and maintain quality of life — means that too many Americans go without the treatment they need. Because our government refuses to stand up to pharmaceutical companies, these medicines cost thousands in the U.S. compared to as little as $75 in other countries. As Senator, I will fight to make sure everyone gets the healthcare they need, and hold pharmaceutical companies accountable so that no one goes without medication because they can’t afford it.
